validation_metadata.verified_by: Claude Code AI Assistant - Manual Extraction
validation_metadata.verification_method: Complete manual review of La. R.S. 44:1 et seq.

rights_of_access.statute_citation: La. Const. Art. XII, ยง 3
rights_of_access.description: No person shall be denied the right to examine public documents except in cases established by law. This constitutional provision provides foundational protection beyond statutory rights.
rights_of_access.conditions: Exceptions must be established by law; constitutional protection means exemptions must have clear legal basis
rights_of_access.applies_to: All persons seeking Louisiana public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Constitutional foundation elevates public access to fundamental right; provides additional basis for challenging denials beyond statutory law
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert constitutional right: 'Louisiana Constitution Article XII, Section 3 guarantees my right to examine public documents. This denial must be based on specific law, not agency discretion.'

rights_of_access.description: Public records are presumed open unless specifically exempted by law. The Act must be construed liberally, and any doubt must be resolved in favor of the right of access.
rights_of_access.conditions: Presumption applies unless specific exemption cited; doubt resolved toward access
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Strong presumption backed by both constitutional and statutory mandates; courts strictly construe exemptions
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite presumption: 'La. R.S. 44:1 presumes public records are open and requires liberal construction favoring access. Please provide [records] pursuant to this statutory presumption.'

rights_of_access.description: The Public Records Act must be construed liberally in favor of access. Any doubt must be resolved toward disclosure, not withholding.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to all interpretations of the Act; mandatory liberal construction; ambiguity favors requester
rights_of_access.applies_to: All Louisiana Public Records Act disputes
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Courts required to interpret broadly in favor of access; agencies cannot use narrow readings to restrict access
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge narrow interpretation: 'La. R.S. 44:1 mandates liberal construction favoring access. Your restrictive interpretation contradicts statutory directive.'

rights_of_access.description: Since 1978 amendments, any person of the age of majority may examine public records. Expanded from previous restriction to only electors and taxpayers.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be age of majority (18+); no residency requirement except for Governor's Office; no taxpayer or voter requirement
rights_of_access.applies_to: All adults regardless of residency (with Governor's Office exception)
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Broad access - non-residents, non-voters, non-taxpayers all have rights; age is only general restriction
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert standing: 'As a person of majority age, La. R.S. 44:1 grants me the right to examine public records. No voter registration or residency is required [except Governor's Office].'

rights_of_access.description: Public agencies must respond to public records requests within 5 business days. Response required whether processing is ongoing or complete.
rights_of_access.conditions: 5 business days from receipt; response mandatory even if records not yet ready; excludes weekends and holidays
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Quick response requirement; failure triggers penalty provisions; response can state records being processed but must respond within 5 days
rights_of_access.request_tips: Track deadline: 'La. R.S. 44:32 requires your response within 5 business days. Please confirm receipt date and response deadline.'

rights_of_access.description: Legal action to compel disclosure may be initiated within 5 days of submitting request. No waiting period beyond initial 5-day response deadline.
rights_of_access.conditions: Can file court action after 5 business days; no requirement to wait longer; no administrative exhaustion required
rights_of_access.applies_to: All requesters whose requests not fulfilled within 5 days
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Fastest court access among states - no administrative appeals or prolonged waiting; can sue on day 6
rights_of_access.request_tips: After 5 days: 'La. R.S. 44:35 authorizes legal action within 5 days of request. If you do not respond by [date], I may immediately file court proceedings.'

rights_of_access.description: Louisiana has no administrative appeal process. Requesters may proceed directly to court for injunction or writ of mandamus without exhausting administrative remedies.
rights_of_access.conditions: Direct court access; no AG review or ombudsman process; can file immediately after denial
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Unusual among states - no bureaucratic appeals process; straight to judicial enforcement; faster resolution
rights_of_access.request_tips: Note enforcement: 'Louisiana has no administrative appeal. Under La. R.S. 44:35, I may file directly in court for injunction or mandamus if this denial continues.'

rights_of_access.description: Custodians who arbitrarily refuse to respond to requests are subject to $100 per day civil penalty. Penalty runs from end of 5-day response period, excluding weekends and legal holidays.
rights_of_access.conditions: Refusal must be arbitrary; penalty is per day; excludes weekends/holidays; attaches to custodian role not individual personally
rights_of_access.applies_to: Custodians who fail to respond or arbitrarily deny
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Daily penalties accumulate quickly - $100/day for 20 business days = $2,000; strong compliance incentive
rights_of_access.request_tips: Reference penalty: 'La. R.S. 44:35(A) imposes $100 daily penalty for arbitrary refusal starting after the 5-day deadline. Please respond to avoid penalty accrual.'

rights_of_access.description: Prevailing plaintiffs are awarded reasonable attorney fees and costs when successfully compelling disclosure. Partial prevails may receive proportionate fees at court discretion.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must prevail in compelling disclosure; fees must be reasonable; court may award partial fees for partial success
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Fee-shifting makes enforcement financially viable; agencies risk paying legal costs if improperly denying; partial success still rewards
rights_of_access.request_tips: Reference fee-shifting: 'La. R.S. 44:35 provides for attorney fees to prevailing plaintiffs. Please comply voluntarily to avoid liability for my legal expenses.'

rights_of_access.description: Public records cases are heard by preference and in summary manner. Appellate courts place these cases on preferential docket. Expedited judicial handling.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to all public records enforcement actions; trial and appellate levels both expedited
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Cases prioritized over regular docket; faster resolution than typical civil cases; courts recognize public interest in prompt access
rights_of_access.request_tips: Note expedited process: 'La. R.S. 44:35 requires preferential treatment for public records cases. Court proceedings will be expedited if this matter is litigated.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must make custodian contact information readily available to the public. Ensures requesters know where to direct requests.
rights_of_access.conditions: Contact information must be readily available; agencies must designate custodian
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Prevents runaround - requesters can identify proper custodian; agencies must publicize contact info
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request custodian info: 'La. R.S. 44:32 requires readily available custodian contact information. Please provide the designated records custodian's name and contact details.'

rights_of_access.description: Courts have consistently held that exemptions must be strictly construed. Agencies cannot broadly interpret exemptions to withhold more than statute explicitly permits.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to all exemption claims; strict construction mandatory; cannot expand exemptions beyond statutory text
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Judicial precedent reinforces legislative mandate; exemptions are narrow exception to constitutional and statutory openness
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge broad exemptions: 'Louisiana courts require strict construction of exemptions per La. R.S. 44:1. Your broad interpretation exceeds statutory authority.'

rights_of_access.description: Public records explicitly include information contained in electronic data processing equipment. Electronic records have same status as paper records regardless of form or characteristics.
rights_of_access.conditions: Format-neutral; includes databases, electronic files, data processing systems; regardless of physical characteristics
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Broad electronic records definition; agencies cannot deny access based on electronic format; databases and systems covered
rights_of_access.request_tips: For electronic records: 'La. R.S. 44:1 defines public records to include information in electronic data processing equipment. Please provide access to [database/electronic files].'

rights_of_access.description: Initial reports of officers investigating criminal matters are public records. While follow-up investigative reports may be exempt during pending litigation, initial incident reports must be disclosed.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to law enforcement initial incident reports; follow-up investigations may be exempt until adjudication; booking records also public
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Distinguishes initial reports (public) from ongoing investigative files (may be exempt); supports transparency in police activity
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request police records: 'La. R.S. 44:3 makes initial officer reports public. I request the initial incident report for [case/incident], which is distinct from ongoing investigative files.'

rights_of_access.statute_citation: La. Code Crim. Proc. Art. 228 (referenced in 44:3)
rights_of_access.description: Booking records, records of summons/citation issuance, and records of bill of information filing are public records under Louisiana law.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to law enforcement booking and citation records; public regardless of pending litigation status
rights_of_access.applies_to: Criminal justice booking and citation records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Ensures transparency in arrests and citations; accessible even during pending cases
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request booking records: 'Booking records are public under Code of Criminal Procedure Article 228 as incorporated in La. R.S. 44:3. Please provide booking records for [individual/date].'

rights_of_access.description: Courts may issue injunctions or writs of mandamus to compel disclosure. Both equitable and legal remedies available to enforce public access rights.
rights_of_access.conditions: Available upon showing of improper denial; court may order immediate compliance; both injunctive and mandamus relief authorized
rights_of_access.applies_to: All enforcement actions for denied requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Multiple remedy types ensure effective enforcement; courts have full authority to compel disclosure
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request relief: 'I will seek injunctive relief and/or writ of mandamus under La. R.S. 44:35 to compel disclosure if this denial is not reconsidered.'

rights_of_access.description: Individual employees are not personally liable for penalties. Liability attaches to the custodian role, not the individual personally, protecting employees while maintaining accountability.
rights_of_access.conditions: Penalties attach to office of custodian not individual; protects employees from personal financial liability
rights_of_access.applies_to: Public employees serving as records custodians
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Balances accountability with fairness; custodians can fulfill duties without personal financial risk; penalties paid by agency
rights_of_access.request_tips: Note to custodian: 'La. R.S. 44:35 protections mean penalties attach to your office, not you personally. You can comply without personal financial risk.'
